projects.name: Mastermind
projects.description: This is a digital clone of the classic board game, Mastermind. One player picks a sequence of (usually) five colours, and the other player has to guess that sequence. The other player only gets a certain number of guesses (ten here), and on each guess, is told if a colour is in the right place or is the right colour but in the wrong place. Note that this version is only single player.

top.name: Noughts & Crosses
top.description: This is my most recent, large, project. At the time, I had stumbled accross a similar Repl by another user and thought to myself (having newly learnt to use Socket.IO and WebSockets) 'I wanna have a go at making my own multiplayer game!' and I knew this was the perfect place start. In less than a week (I think from memory), I managed to create a fully operational, online multiplayer, Noughts & Crosses game. For this project I used NodeJS, with Express for the server (another thing I had recently picked up and wanted to apply), and WebSockets for realtime server-client communications. I integrated Repl Auth to authenticate users as well as the Replit Database, where user stats are stored. These stats are displayed on the leaderboard page where they are also sorted to create friendly competition. The menu page allows players to search for a room, using WebSockets to display new rooms created in real-time. Once in a room, using WebSockets, the two players moves are communicated to the server which handles everything else and responds to each user with the updated board or alerts them that a user has won. This project showcases my skill as a full-stack developer and also demonstrates my ability to quickly learn something new and apply it to a real context. You can easily imagine how the skills required for a project like this can be applied to much larger contexts.

top.name: Skeleton Loading
top.description: Skeleton Loading is a technique used by many very large popular websites such as Facebook. Skeleton Loading involves loading animated placeholder content while real content is being fetched through some form of request. Having recently learnt about Skeleton Loading, I decided to make a simple website to try this out and demonstrate a simple form of Skeleton Loading. Skeleton Loading is a handy skill for both a front-end and full-stack developer, it can be applied to almost any graphical application and has some interesting psychological effects on the perception of load times for users.

top.name: Intro to JS

I won third place overall, winning $250 US with this tutorial: Intro to JS. I made this tutorial in less than a week (from memory) for this Jam.
